results.title: Shanghai noon
results.creator_credit: Tom Dey, Jonathan Glickman, Roger Birnbaum, Gary Barber, Touchstone Pictures, Spyglass Entertainment and Jackie Chan Films
results.brief_description: A case of East meets West in this comic adventure Jackie Chan film set in 1850s American West. Chon Wang (Jackie Chan), an Imperial Guard, is sent across to America as part of a rescue team to find the Emperor’s kidnapped daughter, Princess Pei Pei (Lucy Liu). However it is not long before Chon Wang becomes separated from the search party and finds himself lost out in the vast open spaces of the West where he has a timely encounter with a bright but arrogant train robber by the name of Roy O’Bannon (Owen Wilson). The two become unlikely allies. Cast also includes Brandon Merrill, Roger Yuan.

results.title: Shanghai Express
results.creator_credit: Josef von Sternberg, Adolph Zukor and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: The lightweight plot - an evacuation by train from Peking to Shanghai - is merely the pretext for one of Sternberg’s most successful pieces of stylization, a fruitful collaboration with cinematographer Lee Garmes (and an uncredited James Wong Howe), and writer Jules Furthman. Dietrich plays Shanghai Lily, a ‘coaster’ (a woman who lives by her wits along the Chinese coast) whose scandalous lifestyle is summed up in the films now classic line, ‘It took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily’. Clive Brook’s plays Dietrich’s love interest Captain Donald Harvey, a stuffy Englishman who knew Lily before her infamous lifestyle and is still hurting from her having previously run off on him. Sternberg uses the stop-start cadences of the narrative as a means to evoke the rhythm of the train, while functioning as a kind of time machine confronting the motley group with their pasts as it carries them to their respective fates. However Sternberg’s main point of interest is Dietrich whose status in the film takes on fetishistic proportions, while being gloriously framed and lit in every scene. Cast includes Anna May Wong, Louise Closser Hale, Eugene Pallette, Lawrence Grant. (Awards: Winner, Best Cinematography- Lee Garmes, Academy Awards, 1932)

results.title: Shane Warne
results.creator_credit: Stephen Phillips and Australian Cricket Video
results.brief_description: This is the story of Shane Warne’s mercurial career in his own words. Named one of the five greatest cricketers of the 20th century and Australia’s greatest wicket taker in Test cricket, he commentates on footage of most of the highlights of his career so far, including his Test debut against India in 1991/92, the Test match hat-trick, and the 1999 World Cup victory. He also discusses many amusing behind the scenes tales as well as some of his greatest rivals.

results.title: Shane [Edited version]
results.brief_description: An edited version of the feature film directed by George Stevens. Starring Alan Ladd as the mysterious stranger who assists a family of homesteaders, highlighting the mythology of the Wild West and the image of the American hero.

results.title: Shane
results.creator_credit: Sandra Richardson, Ian Munro, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Shane identifies himself as ‘dumb’. The film examines some of the perceptions his parents, siblings and peers hold about Shane by showing him at his school and at his home. The interactions in these two settings illustrate some causes and consequences of low self-esteem

results.title: Shane
results.brief_description: George Stevens’ legendary rendition of the archetypal Western myth earned six Academy Award nominations and made “Shane” one of the timeless classics of American cinema. Based on on the novel by Jack Schaefer, a drifter and retired gunfighter (Alan Ladd) comes to the assistance of a homestead family terrorized by an aging cattleman and his hired gun. In fighting the last, decisive battle, Shane sees the end of his way of life. The mysterious, moody and breathtakingly atmospheric cinematography by Loyal Griggs won an Oscar and the film is enhanced by the intense performances of its splendid cast particularly Brandon de Wilde as the young son who idolises Shane.

results.title: Shampoo
results.creator_credit: Hal Ashby, Warren Beatty and Vista Company
results.brief_description: A frankly adult comedy about the sex lives of the rich and aimless, “Shampoo” is also a pointed commentary on the demise of the 60s idealism at the dawn of the Nixon era. It is election day, 1968, and Beverly Hills hairdresser George Roundy is too worried about attending to all of his womens’ tonsorial and sexual needs and trying to swing a bank loan to fund his own salon to notice the fateful Presidential race. As George juggles the demands of girlfriend Jill and mistress Felicia, not to mention Felicia’s daughter, he meets Felicia’s husband - Lester, to get money for the salon and discovers that his beloved ex-girlfriend, Jackie is now Lester’s mistress. Lester asks George to escort Jackie to a banquet for Nixon supporters, leading to a series of climactic confrontations at the dinner and a Hollywood orgy that exposes the conflicting demands of sex, love and security among these terminally narcissistic L.A. denizens. Cast includes: Warren Beatty, Julie Christie, Goldie Hawn, Lee Grant, Jack Warden and Carrie Fisher.

results.title: Shame
results.creator_credit: Steve Steve Jodrell, Damien Parer, Paul D. Barron, UAA Films and Barron Films
results.brief_description: Asta Cadell (Deborra-Lee Furness), a city barrister is touring the outback alone when she is forced to stay in a small, isolated town when her motorbike breaks down. During her enforced stay she uncovers the scandal that grips the town in fear, and becomes the catalyst for a dramatic and riveting battle. A disturbing look at the sexual attitudes of an Australian rural society in decline. Also stars Simone Buchanan and Tony Barry.

results.title: Shallow grave
results.creator_credit: Danny Boyle, Andrew Macdonald, Channel 4, Glascow Film Office and Figment Films
results.brief_description: What would you do if your new roommate mysteriously dies, leaving an open suitcase full of money? This is the situation that faces three young professionals (Kerry Fox, Christopher Eccleston and Ewan McGregor) when they take in a new border after stringently screening for a successful applicant. It seems an easy choice to make but when they decide to keep the money it changes their lives and relationships between each other irrevocably. Produced by the creators of “Trainspotting” this black comedy won best acting awards for the three lead performers at the British International Film Festival.

results.title: Shall we dance?
results.creator_credit: Masayuki Suo, Yuji Ogata, Shoji Masui, Tetsuya Ikeda, Nihon Terebi, Nihon Eiga Shin-sha, Hakuhodo, Daiei Motion Picture Company and Altamira Pictures
results.brief_description: Suo’s second feature after his offbeat comic debut “Sumo Do, Sumo Don’t”, this wistful comedy about a Japanese salaryman who discovers the joys of ballroom dancing was hugely successful in its country of origin. Each evening, as he commutes home to his wife and daughter, Shohei Sugiyama, a typically strait-laced Japanese businessmen, catches a glimpse of a beautiful woman gazing out the window of a dance school. Unable to contain his curiosity, he enrols for classes in order to make contact with her. A snooty ex-professional dancer, she keeps her distance from Sugiyama, but through his newfound love of dancing he befriends a group of people who share his secret passion, including an office colleague who becomes a flamboyant mambo king on the dance floor. Touching and uplifting, the film also offers a subtle critique of restrictive cultural norms in a country where ballroom dancing is regarded as a slightly embarrassing, suspicious past-time because of the close physical proximity of the dancers. Cast includes Koji Yakusho, Taoiyo Kusakari, Naoto Takenaka and Eriko Watanabe. In Japanese with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Masayuki Suo, Yuji Ogata, Shoji Masui, Tetsuya Ikeda, Nihon Terebi, Nihon Eiga Shin-sha, Hakuhodo, Daiei Motion Picture Company and Altamira Pictures
